newsitem.title: USA: GM says work stoppages to cost $700 million.
newsitem.headline: GM says work stoppages to cost $700 million.

text.p: General Motors Corp. said Thursday that recent work stoppages at its North American plants will cut fourth-quarter earnings by $700 million.

In a quarterly report with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the world's largest automaker also said it will take a charge against fourth-quarter earnings of $170 million due to lump-sum payments under its recently announced labour agreement.
The automaker was hit by a work stoppage in Canada last month and local strikes in Indianapolis and Wisconsin in late October that spilled over into November.
GM said that $655 million will involve its North American automotive operations while $45 million will cover the Delco Electronics section of its Hughes Electronics unit.

On Monday, GM said the October strikes prompted it to lower its fourth-quarter North American production forecast by 151,000 vehicles. The company now plans to build 1.169 million cars and trucks in North America during the period, down 14.8 percent from a year ago.
